abstract.text: An object that describes a single user interaction with your app.

legalNotices.copyright: Copyright © 2025 Apple Inc. All rights reserved.

inlineContent.text: Apps can receive many different types of events, including touch events, motion events, remote-control events, and press events. Touch events are the most common and are delivered to the view in which the touch originally occurred. Motion events are UIKit triggered and are separate from the motion events reported by the Core Motion framework. Remote-control events allow a responder object to receive commands from an external accessory or headset so that it can manage audio and video â€” for example, playing a video or skipping to the next audio track. Press events represent interactions with a game controller, Apple TV remote, or other device that has physical buttons. You can determine the type of an event using the

A touch event object contains the touches (that is, the fingers on the screen) that have some relation to the event. A touch event object may contain one or more touches, and each touch is represented by a
object. When a touch event occurs, the system routes it to the appropriate responder and calls the appropriate method, such as
. The responder then uses the touches to determine an appropriate course of action.
During a multitouch sequence, UIKit reuses the same

object when delivering updated touch data to your app. You should never retain an event object or any object returned from an event object. If you need to retain data outside of the responder method you use to process that data, copy that data from the
object to your local data structures.
For more information on how to handle events in your UIKit app, see

abstract.text: Construct and manage a graphical, event-driven user interface for your iOS, iPadOS, or tvOS app.
An object that describes a single user interaction with your app.
Constants that indicate which input-device buttons are pressed.
Constants that specify the subtype of the event in relation to its general type.
Constants that specify the general type of an event.
All touches associated with the event.
A bit mask that represents which input-device buttons are pressed for the current event.
Returns all of the touches associated with the specified main touch.
The set of modifier keys that are pressed for the current event.
Returns an array of touches that are predicted to occur for the specified touch.
Returns the subtype of the event.
The time when the event occurred.
Returns the touch objects that are being delivered to the specified gesture recognizer.
Returns the touch objects from the event that belong to the specified window.
Returns the touch objects from the event that belong to the specified given view.
Returns the type of the event.
Constants that indicate which modifier keys are pressed.
An event that describes the state of a set of physical buttons that are available to the device, such as those on an associated remote or game controller.
An abstract interface for responding to and handling events.
Tells this object that one or more new touches occurred in a view or window.
An object representing the location, size, movement, and force of a touch occurring on the screen.
Handle user input by connecting buttons, sliders, and other controls to your appâ€™s code using the target-action design pattern.

abstract.text: Learn how to handle events that propagate through your app.

doc://com.apple.uikit/documentation/UIKi.title: Using responders and the responder chain to handle events

abstract.text: The root class of most Objective-C class hierarchies, from which subclasses inherit a basic interface to the runtime system and the ability to behave as Objective-C objects.
The group of methods that are fundamental to all Objective-C objects.
A type that can be hashed into a `Hasher` to produce an integer hash value.
A type that can be compared for value equality.
A singleton actor whose executor is equivalent to the main dispatch queue.
A type with a customized textual representation.
A type with a customized textual representation suitable for debugging purposes.
A type whose instances can be encoded, and appropriately passed, as elements of a C `va_list`.
A thread-safe type whose values can be shared across arbitrary concurrent contexts without introducing a risk of data races.

https://developer.apple.com/library/arch.title: Event Handling Guide for UIKit Apps
